Award.AwardTitle: Design, synthesis, and applications of a uniquely multi-functionalized small organoboron molecule for organic synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Takashi Tomioka of the Department of Chemistry at University of Mississippi will explore the synthetic applications of a unique, multi-functionalized small organoboron molecule, diaminoboryl acetonitrile. Despite its structural simplicity as well as potential importance, no study for its use in organic synthesis has been developed. The deprotonation of the acidic hydrogen on the methylene carbon of diaminoboryl acetonitrile with an appropriate base should generate a novel, nucleophilic alpha-diaminoboryl carbanion species that could be utilized for a variety of practical applications in chemical synthesis.

Installing and transforming functionalities on organic molecules are the most fundamental and crucial technologies in chemical synthesis, which is needed to address the ever-increasing demand on complex organic molecules. This project intends to develop new and efficient synthetic methodology based on the unique chemistry of diaminoboryl acetonitrile. If successful, it will positively impact any area of activities where the synthesis of organic molecules is needed. These areas of activities include the pharmaceutical, agrochemical, and specialty chemical industries. The project will also provide excellent trainings to the graduate students and undergraduate students involved, including those currently underrepresented in Chemistry.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we explored the chemistry of a new set of reagents that possess a negatively-charged carbon next to a boron atom. The resulting anions are able to connect with other reagents. In particular, the reaction with aldehydes or ketones gives products in which the three-dimensional positioning (the "stereochemistry") of the carbon-carbon double bond that links the two components is well controlled. This provides more efficient ways to prepare a variety of target molecules. Among the targets made previously in the project were quinoline and indene alkaloids, which can be used in biochemical and medicinal chemical studies. While exploring an unexpected byproduct, we discovered a novel reaction that adds one carbon to epoxides to make alcohol products with an unusual substitution pattern. Reactions that perform specific transformations like this are useful tools in the repertoire of synthetic chemists.

In the current reporting period, we used the anionic boron reagent to link together the donor and acceptor halves of molecules expected to be molecular rectifiers. Rectifiers allow electrical current to pass in only one direction, and molecules that are rectifiers may allow electrical circuits to be fabricated on a nano scale, smaller and faster than circuits now in use.

Two of the graduate students who trained under the project are now working in chemical industry; a third is continuing his research, and the two undergraduates who trained under the project are headed towards promising careers.

 


Last Modified: 08/10/2016
Modified by: Daniell L Mattern

The resulting anions are able to connect with other reagents. While exploring an unexpected byproduct, we discovered a novel reaction that adds one carbon to epoxides to make alcohol products with an unusual substitution pattern. Reactions that perform specific transformations like this are useful tools in the repertoire of synthetic chemists. Rectifiers allow electrical current to pass in only one direction, and molecules that are rectifiers may allow electrical circuits to be fabricated on a nano scale, smaller and faster than circuits now in use.
